text: It treats the first report, which was not allowed to investigate whether the administration lief about intel, as if it cleared the administration of lying. And then pretends the second report, which found it did lie, never happened.
author: jonathanchait

text: The argument used by Bush defenders was and is a very crude lie. They simply pretend the Phase II report did not exist. @AriFleischer's thread is very typical: it refers to a report, singular.
author: jonathanchait

text: The first report, looking exclusively at failures by intelligence, was eventually called Phase I. The report finding how the administration distorted intelligence was called the Phase II report.
author: jonathanchait

text:
After Democrats won the Senate in 2006, they forced an investigation into whether the administration lied.

Conclusion: It did. “the Administration repeatedly presented intelligence as fact when in reality it was unsubstantiated, contradicted, or even non-existent.”
author: jonathanchait

text: Since Bush defenders keep circulating the same myths, I will correct in a short thread. The first commission was blocked by Republicans from considering how the administration distorted intelligence.
author: jonathanchait

text:
When it comes to things like shutting down speeches, which they can use as spectacles of free speech martyrdom, I disagree.

On issues like being hosted on social media platforms, you may be right.
author: jonathanchait

text:
College Republicans inviting, say, Milo to speak at your campus is a bad choice.

Opponents responding by trying to shut down the speech is also a bad choice.
author: jonathanchait

text: Right, but my contention is that allowing them to pose as free speech martyrs, whose message is so powerful its opponents fear to allow it to be stated, helps rather than hinders their recruiting.
author: jonathanchait

text: To give just one example: The radical tactic of deplatforming racists on campuses gave them the bad-boy allure of the forbidden they craved.
author: jonathanchait

text: Some Democratic candidate looking for a unifying theme for their economic policy might think about picking this up.
